comms_internal: Interestingly, in CV structures like this one, the head of the ezafe construction always bears a masculine suffix, unlike regular productive ezafe constructions.

US: “In Zazaki, zere as a noun that means inside. However, it can also be said to function as a preposition when it forms an ezafe structure with another noun. zereyê keyeyî 'inside the house', zereyê wendegeyî 'inside the school'. When these ezafe phrases come after verbs expressing movement, i.e. when they are placed in the target position, zereyê automatically means 'into/for'.”

comms: Not included in the database because Y is expressed as an NP-internal modifier.
comms_internal: US: “The possessor part of the intervening ezafe becomes the object of the verb. zor 'difficult', berdene 'to take away', zor-e ... berdene 'to beat someone'”.

comms: CV

comms_internal: In the present tense, Oxir will be unmarked. Here, “=re” is a postposition and cannot be used a preposition.

US: “In Zazaki, as in Kurmanji, the verb pê.girewtene means to hold an object, something. “girewtene” by itself means ‘to get, take’ and I know that it comes from the same root as grab in English. With pê, it means ‘to hold’.”

The verb agrees with the subject (e.g. “-ɛ” with a feminine subject). The GOAL is marked by OBL because it is high on the animacy scale. It can not be indexed and is not a direct object. And it comes always after the verb.

back_translation_en: ‘He reached the bank of the river.’
comms_internal: The verb agrees with the subject (cf. a rɛʃt-ɛ 'She reached' ). The Y argument is obligatorily placed after the verb. The goal is marked by OBL only if it is high on the animacy scale (which is unusual for goals; but this is possible in something like ‘he reached me’).

CV. If the object were a pronoun here, it would be used in an OBL form. Normally the subject pronoun ‘a’ should have been in the initial position in the sentence. However, its place is changed for topicality. In this sentence we understand that it is ‘she’ who is running the city, not someone else. If we turn this sentence into past, the subject would be in the OBL form: "aye" [she.obl]. "ajɛ ʃarɨstan-i idarɛ kɛrd-enɛ"
